conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B, let's analyze the problem step by step.
Car A has a constant speed of 40 m/s from t = 10 to t = 30 s.
Car B starts from rest and accelerates uniformly with a continuous increase in velocity.
The distance covered by a car can be found by calculating the area under its velocity-time (v-t) graph.
Distance covered by Car A is 800 m from t = 10 to t = 30 s.
From t = 0 to t = 20 s, Car B's velocity increases linearly to 40 m/s.
Distance covered by Car B from t = 0 to t = 20 s is 400 m.
From t = 20 to t = 30 s, Car B's velocity continues to increase linearly.
To find the exact distance for Car B from t = 20 to t = 30 s, we need the slope of the line.
Distance of Car A by t = 20 s is 400 m.
Distance of Car B by t = 20 s is 400 m.
Distance of Car A from t = 20 to t = 30 s is 400 m.
Distance of Car B from t = 20 to t = 30 s is the area under the graph from 20 to 30 s.
The separation is maximized when Car B has not yet covered the same distance as Car A.
